profile: Nutrition Foundations: Evidence-Based Roles of Food Groups

importance: Rich in vitamins (C, A, folate), minerals (potassium, magnesium), and antioxidants (polyphenols, flavonoids).
Provide natural sugars for glycogen replenishment after exercise.
key_effects: Antioxidants reduce oxidative stress and inflammation, supporting recovery.
High fiber improves digestion and gut microbiome balance.
Certain fruits (bananas, kiwis, tart cherries) have sleep and recovery benefits.
evidence: Howatson et al. (2012). Tart cherry improves recovery and sleep. Eur J Nutr.
Lin et al. (2011). Kiwi improved sleep onset. Asia Pac J Clin Nutr.

importance: Low-calorie, high in fiber, vitamins, and phytonutrients.
Provide nitrates (beets, spinach) that enhance blood flow and endurance.
key_effects: Cruciferous vegetables support detoxification and hormone balance.
Nitrate-rich vegetables increase nitric oxide, improving VO2 max and endurance.
Antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects enhance recovery and immunity.
evidence: Lansley et al. (2011). Beetroot juice improves endurance. J Appl Physiol.
Aune et al. (2017). High vegetable intake reduces chronic disease risk. Int J Epidemiol.

importance: Source of essential amino acids (EAAs), especially leucine for muscle protein synthesis.
Supports repair, recovery, and lean mass preservation during fat loss.
key_effects: Post-exercise protein (20–40 g with 2–3 g leucine) stimulates maximal MPS.
Casein before bed improves overnight recovery.
High protein diets increase satiety and thermogenesis.
evidence: Moore et al. (2009). 20–25 g whey stimulates MPS. J Appl Physiol.
Res et al. (2012). Casein before sleep enhances overnight MPS. Med Sci Sports Exerc.

importance: Provide complex carbohydrates, fiber, B vitamins, iron, magnesium.
Main source of glycogen replenishment for athletes.
key_effects: Whole grains stabilize blood sugar and improve satiety.
Fiber improves gut health and lowers LDL cholesterol.
Timing: post-exercise carbs (1–1.2 g/kg/hr for 4–6 hrs) maximize glycogen resynthesis.
evidence: Ivy et al. (1988). Post-exercise carbs accelerate glycogen replenishment. J Appl Physiol.
Aune et al. (2016). Whole grain intake reduces disease risk. BMJ.

importance: Essential for hormone production, cell membranes, and brain function.
Omega-3 fatty acids reduce inflammation and improve recovery.
key_effects: Adequate fats (20–35% of calories) support testosterone and growth hormone.
Omega-3 supplementation improves muscle recovery and reduces DOMS.
Monounsaturated fats (olive oil, nuts) support cardiovascular health.
evidence: Jouris et al. (2011). Omega-3 reduces inflammation and aids recovery. J Diet Suppl.
Estruch et al. (2013). Mediterranean diet lowers mortality. NEJM.
